title: Are wages considered community property? Can I garnish wages to collect on a judgment if defendant's spouse is in bankruptcy?
question: I recently was awarded a judgment and the defendant will not pay what is due. I plan to have her wages garnished, but her husband has filed chapter 7. She is not listed as a co-debtor and her wages are not claimed on their bankruptcy forms (she is listed as unemployed).
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Automatic stays in bankruptcy,Bankruptcy documents,Debt,Wage garnishment,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud,Spousal debt
answers:
If the wife is not filing there is no stay as to her, but there is a stay as to the husband.

Wages will become community property once earned generally. Since the wife has no wages you cannot garnish her wages. Since the H is not liable for the spouses debt you may not garnish his wages. You could levy on their bank accounts, but I would advise not doing so until the BK is concluded as to do so may result in a violation of the auto. stay.


BW

I'd a little unclear here. First, as a general notion, since the wife didn't file bankruptcy, her wages are free-and-clear as far as garnishment is concerned - community property doesn't protect them. But, if she is listed as "unemployed" in the husband's bankruptcy petition, why do you think she has wages to garnish? Either you're wrong, and the wife is unemployed, or the husband committed bankruptcy fraud, which should be brought to the attention of the court.
